title-group.article-title: Acute effects of methiocarb on oxidative damage and the protective effects of vitamin E and taurine in the liver and kidney of Wistar rats

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Pharmaceutical Toxicology, Istanbul University, Beyazit, Istanbul, Turkey
2Department of Biology, Istanbul University, Vezneciler, Istanbul, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Buket Alpertunga, Department of Pharmaceutical Toxicology, Faculty of Pharmacy, Istanbul University, 34116 Beyazit, Istanbul, Turkey. Email: tunga@istanbul.edu.tr

abstract.p: Methiocarb (MC) is a widely used carbamate pesticide in agriculture and health programs. Although the main molecular mechanism of carbamate toxicity involves acetylcholinesterase inhibition, studies have also implicated the induction of oxidative stress. Therefore, the present study was aimed to evaluate the effect of acute MC exposure on lipid peroxidation, antioxidant defense systems, histological changes in Wistar rats and the protective effect of pretreatment with vitamin E and taurine. A total of 48 rats were randomly divided into six groups. Rats in group I were given corn oil, while those in group III were dosed with vitamin E (100 mg/kg body weight (b.w.)) and in group V were dosed with taurine (50 mg/kg b.w.). Rats in group II were administered with MC only (25 mg/kg b.w., 1/4 of median lethal dose (LD50)), while those in groups IV and VI were pretreated with vitamin E (100 mg/kg b.w.) and taurine (50 mg/kg b.w.) for 20 days, respectively, and then exposed to MC (25 mg/kg b.w.). The rats administered with MC showed significant increase in the levels of malondialdehyde in the liver and kidney as an index of lipid peroxidation. Levels of glutathione and activities of superoxide dismutase, catalase and glutathione peroxidase were significantly increased, while activity of glutathione reductase remained unchanged in both the tissues after MC treatment. Mild degenerative histological changes were observed in liver tissue, while the changes in kidney tissue were more severe then liver after MC treatment. Pretreatment with vitamin E and taurine resulted in a significant decrease in the lipid peroxidation and alleviating effects on antioxidant defense systems in both the tissues, while protective effects on the histological changes were shown only in kidney when compared with liver. In conclusion, the study has demonstrated that the acute MC exposure in Wistar rats caused oxidative damage on liver and kidney, which were partly ameliorated by the pretreatment of vitamin E and taurine.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Methiocarb (3,5-dimethyl-4-(methylthio) phenol methylcarbamate; MC) is a carbamate pesticide with insecticidal, acaricidal and molluscicidal activity. It has been used since 1960s as a pesticide for a variety of invertebrate pests and also used as a bird repellent on fruit crops (Hayes and Laws, 1991). MC exhibits a wide range of toxicity in mammals by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase and the consequent accumulation of acetylcholine leading to cholinergic stimulation (Ecobichon, 1996). It has high acute toxicity with median lethal dose (LD50) of 100 mg/kg b.w. on rats (Methiocarb JMPR, 1998) and is classified as a highly hazardous (Class 1B) compound for acute oral effects by World Health Organization (Methiocarb RED Fact Sheet, 1994). In 2007, MC was included in an endocrine disrupter screening program of the US Environmental Protection Agency due to its multiple exposure pathways and high production volume (Han et al., 2009). The widespread use of pesticides has caused severe environmental pollution and health hazards, including cases of severe acute and chronic human poisoning. Residual amounts of MC have been monitored in the water, soil, honey, plants, fruits and vegetables (Blasco et al., 2005; González-Rodríguez et al., 2008; Huertas-Pérez and García-Campaña, 2008; Picó and Kozmutza, 2007; Pirard et al., 2007; Saraji and Esteki, 2008; Strankowski and Stanley, 1981; Topuz and Alpertunga, 2003; Wilsont and Foos, 2006). Moreover, the first clear report on the fatal poisoning of a human with MC has been reported recently (Thierauf et al., 2009). Despite extensive use of MC, very limited studies on the mechanisms of its action other than the inhibition of acetylcholinesterase activity are currently available.

Free radicals play an important role in the toxicity of pesticides. Recent studies showed that the toxic manifestations induced by carbamates may be associated with the induction of oxidative stress through the generation of free radicals and alteration in antioxidant systems (Banks and Soliman, 1997; Eraslan et al., 2009a,b; Kamboj et al., 2006; Kaur and Sandhir, 2006; Maran et al., 2009; Rai et al., 2009; Rai and Sharma, 2007; Seth et al., 2000, 2001; Suke et al., 2006; Yarsan et al., 1999). In an earlier study, we have reported the induction of oxidative stress following subacute exposure to MC and alterations in the histology of liver and kidney and protective effects of vitamin E and taurine on MC-induced oxidative damage (Ozden et al., 2009). Moreover, we observed an increase in lipid peroxidation and alterations in the levels of glutathione after acute (1/4 of LD50) and subacute (1/10 and 1/50 of LD50) exposures to MC in the liver, kidney, brain and testis of rats (Ozden and Alpertunga, 2010). In the present study, in correlation with our mentioned previous studies, the aims were to highlight the acute effects of MC on antioxidant defense mechanisms and histological alterations in the liver and kidney of rats.

Vitamin E is the most effective chain breaking lipid soluble antioxidant in the biological membranes and protects cellular structures against the damage of oxygen free radicals and reactive products of lipid peroxidation (Sies and Murphy, 1991). To date, several studies indicated that vitamin E inhibits lipid peroxidation and attenuated the antioxidant enzyme activities following pesticide exposures (Aldana et al., 2001; Atessahin et al., 2005; Durak et al., 2009; el-Demerdash et al., 2004; Garg et al., 2008; Giray et al., 2001; John et al., 2001; Kalender et al., 2004; 2005; Sodhi et al., 2008; Uzun et al., 2009; Yousef et al., 2006). Taurine (2-aminoethanesulfonic acid), a ubiquitous free amino acid, is present in most mammalian tissues. It is known to have various physiologic functions in cell metabolism including osmoregulation, membrane stabilization, detoxification and regulation of cellular calcium homeostasis (Huxtable, 1992). Taurine exhibits a protective effect against oxidation induced by cellular stress and behaves as a free radical scavenger in various cells and tissues against toxic injury of oxidant compounds (Hagar, 2004; Timbrell et al., 1995; Waters et al., 2001). It has been shown that taurine inhibits lipid peroxidation and attenuated the antioxidant enzymes activities following xenobiotics exposure (Das et al., 2009; Dogru-Abbasoglu et al., 2001; Gurer et al., 2001; Hagar et al., 2006; Hwang et al., 1998; Jagadeesan and Sankarsami Pillai, 2007; Manna et al., 2009; Sener et al., 2005a,b; Tabassum et al., 2006). However, there is no report to show the protective effects of taurine in short-term pesticide-induced oxidative damage, while vitamin E is known to be protective.

Due to the fact that MC is sulfoxidated by human kidney and liver microsomes and also kidney and liver are the only tissues for the radioactive residues of MC sulfoxide as a metabolite in dairy cows, it has been suggested that the liver and kidney are the major target tissues after MC exposure. While it is becoming recognized as a suspected endocrin disrupter, we were unable to find any report on the prooxidant/antioxidant status of liver and kidney in experimental animals after acute exposure to MC. Thus, the objectives of the present study were (i) to evaluate the acute effects of MC on lipid peroxidation, reduced glutathione (GSH) and antioxidant enzyme systems such as superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px) and glutathione reductase (GSH-Rd), (ii) to investigate the ensuing histological changes and (iii) to investigate the putative protective effects of taurine comparison with vitamin E against MC-induced oxidative damage in liver and kidney.

sec.title: Chemicals
sec.p: MC (also known by the trade name Mesurol), technical purity 99.8%, was obtained from Bayer (Istanbul, Turkey). Vitamin E (Evigen, 300 mg d,l-α-tocopherol acetate) was purchased from Aksu Farma (Istanbul, Turkey). Taurine and all other chemicals were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Chemicals Co (St Louis, Missouri, USA) and Merck (Darmstadt, Germany).

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: Male Wistar Albino rats, aged 12–13 weeks and weighed 160 ± 20 g were used in this study. Animals were kept in clean polypropylene cages under standard laboratory conditions (temperature at 25 ± 2°C, relative humidity of 50 ± 15% and normal photoperiod of 12–12 h light–dark cycle) with free access to standard dry pellet diet and water ad libitum. All the treatments were started after almost 1 week of stabilization from arrival.

The experiments reported here complied with the current laws and regulations of the Turkish Republic on the care and handling of experimental animals and the Animal Ethical Committee of Cerrahpasa Faculty of Medicine, Turkey.

sec.title: Animal treatments
sec.p:
The animals were randomly divided into six experimental groups each containing eight rats. The substances were administered in the morning (between 9:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m.) to nonfasted rats.
Group I (C): Rats received intragastrically (i.g.) the equivalent volumes of corn oil (0.5 ml per animal) instead of MC for 1 day.
Group II (MC): MC at the dose of 25 mg/kg b.w. (1/4 of LD50) in corn oil was applied to rats i.g. for 1 day. Dose selection of MC (25 mg/kg b.w.; 1/4 of LD50) was based on our previous study, which showed that this dose induce lipid peroxidation in rat tissues (Ozden and Alpertunga, 2010).
Group III (Vit E): Commercially available vitamin E at the dosage of 100 mg/kg b.w in olive oil (0.5 ml per animal) was applied to the rats intraperitoneally (i.p.) once a day for 21 days. Dose selection of vitamin E (100 mg/kg b.w.) was based on the published studies, which showed that this dose was effective against the toxicity induced by pesticides (MC, deltamethrin and fenvalerate) (el-Demerdash et al., 2004; Ozden et al., 2009; Yousef et al., 2006).
Group IV (Vit E + MC): Before MC treatment, rats were pretreated i.p. with vitamin E (100 mg/kg b.w.) once a day for 20 days and then MC at the above-mentioned dose was applied along with vitamin E for 1 day.
Group V (T): Taurine at the dose of 50 mg/kg b.w. in distilled water (0.5 ml per animal) was given to the rats i.p. once a day for 21 days. Dose selection of taurine (50 mg/kg b.w.) was also based on the published studies, which showed that this dose was effective against the toxicity induced by various xenobiotics (Cetiner et al., 2005; Ozden et al., 2009; Sener et al., 2004, 2005a,b).
Group VI (T + MC): Before MC treatment, rats were pretreated i.p. with taurine (50 mg/kg b.w.) once a day for 20 days and then MC at the above-mentioned dose was applied along with taurine for 1 day.
The pretreatment of vitamin E and taurine was provided in order to build antioxidant pool in animal body before pesticide exposure.

Twenty-four hours after the last treatment, the rats were killed by cervical dislocation. Liver and kidney samples were dissected out and washed immediately with ice-cold physiological saline (0.9% NaCl) and one part of both of the tissues were immediately stored at −80°C until analysis. The other parts of both of the tissues were taken from the rats for histological analysis.

sec.title: Preparation of tissues
sec.p: The tissues were homogenized in 0.9% NaCl using a tissue homogenizer (Basic Ultra-Turrax T-18, IKA Werke GmbH&Co., Staufen, Germany) to make up the 10% homogenate (w/v) and then centrifuged at 10,000g for 20 min at 4°C to obtain cytosolic fraction. Tissue homogenates (10%) were used to determine the levels of GSH and lipid peroxidation. Cytosolic fractions of tissue homogenates (10%) were used to determine the activities of antioxidant enzymes.

sec.title: Lipid peroxidation assay
sec.p: Quantitative measurement of lipid peroxidation was performed in liver and kidney homogenates (10%) according to the method of Buege and Aust (1976), which is based on the formation of thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS) and expressed as the extent of malondialdehyde (MDA) production. The amount of TBARS was determined in tissue homogenates using reversed-phase high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with ultraviolet diode-array detection (Thermo Separation Products, California, USA) at 532 nm according to the modification of the HPLC method of Draper and Hadley (1990). The levels of TBARS were calculated using 1,1,3,3-tetraethoxypropane as the standard and expressed as nanomoles of MDA per milligram of protein (Ozden et al., 2009).

sec.title: GSH assay
sec.p: Levels of GSH were determined in the liver and kidney homogenates (10%) according to the method of Beutler (1975) using 5,5′-dithiobis-2-nitrobenzoic acid (DTNB) reagent. DTNB was reduced by free –SH group of GSH to form 5-mercapto-2-nitrobenzoate, and its absorbance was measured by spectrophotometric means at 412 nm. Results were expressed as micromoles of GSH per milligram of protein using standard calibration curve.

sec.title: SOD assay
sec.p: Activity of SOD was determined in the cytosolic fractions of liver and kidney homogenates according to the method of Sun et al. (1998). The principle of the method is based on the inhibition of nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) reduction using the xanthine–xanthine oxidase system as a superoxide generator. Activity was assessed in the supernatants of 10,000g of ethanol/chloroform (5/3, v/v) extracts of tissue homogenates (10%). One unit of SOD was defined as the enzyme amount causing 50% inhibition in NBT reduction rate. Specific activity was expressed as the unit SOD per milligram of protein using standard calibration curve.

sec.title: CAT assay
sec.p: Activity of CAT was assayed in the cytosolic fractions of liver and kidney homogenates by the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide according to the method of Aebi (1984). This reaction follows a first-order kinetic given by equation k = (2.3/t) (log A0/A1). Specific activity was expressed as k per milligram of protein using standard calibration curve.

sec.title: GSH-Px assay
sec.p: Activity of GSH-Px was determined in the cytosolic fractions of liver and kidney homogenates according to the method of Pleban et al. (1982). The principle of this method is based on the decrease in absorbance of reduced form of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH) at 340 nm. GSH-Px catalyzes the oxidation of glutathione by hydrogen peroxide. In the presence of GSH-Rd and NADPH, oxidized glutathione (glutathione disulphide (GSSG)) is immediately converted to the reduced form with a concominant oxidation of NADPH to NADP+. Specific activity was expressed as unit GSH-Px per milligram of protein using standard calibration curve. One unit of GSH-Px is defined as the amount of enzyme that oxidizes 1 μmol of NADPH per minute.

sec.title: GSH-Rd assay
sec.p: Activity of GSH-Rd was performed in the cytosolic fractions of liver and kidney homogenates by monitoring the oxidation of NADPH in the presence of oxidized glutathione according to the method of Beutler (1969). Specific activity was expressed as milliunit GSH-Rd per milligram of protein using standard calibration curve. One unit of GSH-Rd is defined as the amount of enzyme that oxidizes 1 μmol of NADPH per minute.

sec.title: Protein assay
sec.p: The content of protein was measured in the liver and kidney homogenates (10%), and cytosolic fractions of liver and kidney homogenates were measured according to the method of Lowry et al. (1951) using bovine serum albumin as standard.

sec.title: Histological examinations
sec.p: Liver and kidney tissues were cut into small pieces and fixed in Bouin’s solution. Following dehydration in an ascending series of ethanol, tissue samples were cleared in xylene and embedded in paraffin and sliced in 5 μm sections. Slides were stained with Masson’s triple dyes (Masson). All sections were examined under a light microscope (Olympus-CX 41).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All data are expressed as mean ± SD. Data were analyzed by analysis of variance test using SPSS version 13.0 for Windows, statistical program and the individual comparisons of groups were obtained using Scheffe’s multiple comparison procedure. p < 0.05 and p < 0.001 were selected as the levels of significance.

sec.title: Biochemical evaluations
sec.p: None of the rats treated with MC at the dose of 25 mg/kg b.w. (1/4 of LD50) showed sign of morbidity or mortality during the studies. As shown in Figures 1–6, treatment of rats with vitamin E and taurine alone did not affect the levels of MDA and GSH and the activities of SOD, CAT, GSH-Px and GSH-Rd in the liver and kidney when compared with the vehicle control groups.

caption.p: The effects of vitamin E and taurine on the content of MDA (nanomoles per milligram of protein) in the liver and kidney of rats treated with MC. Values are expressed as mean ± SD; n = 8 for each treatment group. a: Significantly different from control group (p < 0.001). b: Significantly different from MC group (p < 0.001; one-way analysis of variance). MDA: malondialdehyde; MC: methiocarb.

sec.p: Acute exposure to MC significantly increased the content of MDA, an end product of lipid peroxidation, 2.33-fold in liver (p < 0.001) and 1.54-fold in kidney (p < 0.001) when compared with the vehicle control group (Figure 1). Pretreatment with vitamin E and taurine resulted in a significant decrease in the content of hepatic (p < 0.001) and renal (p < 0.001) MDA when compared with the MC group. As depicted in Figure 2, the level of GSH in the rats treated with MC was significantly increased in liver (25%, p < 0.001) and kidney (33%, p < 0.001) when compared with the vehicle control group. However, pretreatment with vitamin E and taurine resulted in a significant decrease in the level of hepatic (p < 0.05) and renal (p < 0.05) GSH in comparison with that of the MC group.

caption.p: The effects of vitamin E and taurine on the levels of GSH (micromoles per milligrams of protein) in the liver and kidney of rats treated with MC. Values are expressed as mean ± SD; n = 8 for each treatment group. a: Significantly different from control group (p < 0.001). b: Significantly different from MC group (p < 0.05; one-way analysis of variance). GSH: glutathione; MC: methiocarb.

sec.p: As presented in Figure 3, the activity of SOD in MC group was significantly increased in liver (35%, p < 0.001) and kidney (26%, p < 0.05) when compared with the vehicle control group. However, pretreatment with vitamin E and taurine resulted in a significant decrease in the activity of SOD in liver (p < 0.05) and kidney (p < 0.05) in comparison with that of the MC group. As depicted in Figure 4, the activity of CAT in the MC group was significantly increased in the liver (22%, p < 0.001) and kidney (19%, p < 0.05) of rats when compared with the vehicle control group. However, the activity of CAT was significantly decreased by vitamin E and taurine pretreatment in liver (p < 0.001) and kidney (p < 0.05) when compared with the MC group. As shown in Figure 5, the activity of GSH-Px in the MC group was significantly increased in liver (31%, p < 0.001) and kidney (30%, p < 0.05) when compared with the vehicle control group. However, pretreatment with vitamin E and taurine resulted in a significant decrease in the activity of GSH-Px in liver (p < 0.001) and kidney (p < 0.05) in comparison with that of the MC group. As shown in Figure 6, the activity of GSH-Rd in the MC group has remained unchanged in liver and kidney when compared with the vehicle control group. Pretreatment with vitamin E and taurine along with MC showed no change in the activity of GSH-Rd in liver and kidney when compared with the MC group.

caption.p: The effects of vitamin E and taurine on the activities of SOD (units per milligram of protein) in the liver and kidney of rats treated with MC. Values are expressed as mean ± SD; n = 8 for each treatment group. a: Significantly different from control group (p < 0.001). b: Significantly different from MC group (p < 0.05). c: Significantly different from control group (p < 0.05; one-way analysis of variance). SOD: superoxide dismutase; MC: methiocarb.

The effects of vitamin E and taurine on the activities of CAT of (Boltzmann constant per milligram of protein) in the liver and kidney of rats treated with MC. Values are expressed as mean ± SD; n = 8 for each treatment group. a: Significantly different from control group (p < 0.001). b: Significantly different from MC group (p < 0.001). c: Significantly different from control group (p < 0.05). d: Significantly different from MC group (p < 0.05; one-way analysis of variance). CAT: catalase; MC: methiocarb.

The effects of vitamin E and taurine on the activities of GSH-Px (unit per milligram of protein) in the liver and kidney of rats treated with MC. Values are expressed as mean ± SD; n = 8 for each treatment group. a: Significantly different from control group (p < 0.001). b: Significantly different from MC group (p < 0.001). c: Significantly different from control group (p < 0.05). d: Significantly different from MC group (p < 0.05; one-way analysis of variance). GSH-Px: glutathione peroxidase; MC: methiocarb.

sec.title: Histological examinations
sec.p: The results of the histological observations showed that the livers of control animals have a normal histological appearance except of a partly histological change that was noticed in the liver treated with vitamin E and taurine. Mild degenerative changes such as a moderate hyperemia and mild sinusoidal dilatations, vacuolization and accumulation of collagen fibers around veins were observed after acute exposure to MC (Figure 7(a)). It was observed that in the presence of vitamin E (Figure 7(b)) and taurine (Figure 7(c)) mild degeneration in the liver tissue was still visible. The kidneys of control animals have a normal histological appearance except of a partly histological change in the kidney tissues of some animals. Widening between parietal and visceral leaves of Bowman’s capsules, shortening at the brush border, cytoplasmic debris and desquamated nuclei in the widened lumens of proximal tubules were determined after acute exposure to MC (Figure 7(d)). On the other hand, in the presence of vitamin E (Figure 7(e)) and taurine (Figure 7(f)), the moderate kidney damage was decreased in the groups treated with MC.

caption.p: The effects of vitamin E and taurine on the activities of GSH-Rd (milliunits per milligram of protein) in the liver and kidney of rats treated with MC. Values are expressed as mean ± SD; n = 8 for each treatment group. GSH-Rd: glutathione reductase; MC: methiocarb.

The effects of vitamin E and taurine on the histological changes in the liver (a–c) and kidney (d–f) of rats treated with MC. Liver tissues of rats in MC group (a), in Vit E + MC group (b) and in T + MC group (c). Vacuolization (➤), hyperemia (H), sinusoidal dilatation (✸) and accumulation of collagen fibers around veins (➞); Masson X270. Kidney tissues of rats in MC group (d), in Vit E + MC group (e) and in T + MC group (f). The widening between parietal and visseral leaves of Bowman capsules (↔), the shortening at the brush border (➞) and desquamated nuclei (➤) in the proximal tubules (P), glomerulus (G) and distal tubule (DT); Masson X270.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Oxidative damage may be the primary cause of subcellular effects of pesticide toxicity. Recent studies of varying duration of exposure with carbamate pesticides have postulated a putative role for the generation of free radicals during the process. Liver plays a central role in the detoxification process and, along with the kidney, faces the threat of maximum exposure to xenobiotics. Therefore, we evaluated the potential effects of MC on oxidative damage in liver and kidney tissues.

We observed a significant increase in the hepatic and renal contents of MDA after acute exposure, indicating increased lipid peroxidation caused by the administration of MC. It has been suggested in our previous study that the radicals may be generated during the metabolism of MC by the cytochrome P450-oxidase and flavin-containing monooxygenase (FMO) enzyme systems and induce lipid peroxidation (Ozden and Alpertunga, 2010). Pretreatment with vitamin E resulted in higher decrease in the content of MDA in liver (57%) and kidney (29%) than taurine (46% in liver and 21% in kidney) when compared with the MC group. However, the significant decrease in the hepatic and renal MDA content confirms that the pretreatment with vitamin E and taurine could effectively protect against the hepatic and renal lipid peroxidation induced by MC. These findings are in accordance with the study of Garg et al. (2008), who reported that the pretreatment with vitamin E decreased the levels of MDA after single dose of methomyl administration in rat erythrocytes.

We reported that the increase in the levels of GSH in liver and kidney may be an adaptive response as an antioxidant to scavenge free radical reactions initiated by MC (Ozden and Alpertunga, 2010). The increase may be due to the acute exposure because GSH was shown to be decreased in our previous study testing the subacute effects of MC (Ozden et al., 2009). Sharma et al. (2005) observed the increased levels of GSH in the rat brain tissue following exposure to dimethoate at 90 mg/kg (%30 LD50). John et al. (2001) also reported that the oral administration of single dose of dimethoate and malathion increased the levels of GSH in rat erythrocytes, and the pretreatment of vitamin E may ameliorate organophosphate-induced oxidative stress. However, pretreatment with vitamin E and taurine normalized the elevated levels of GSH after acute exposure to MC in liver and kidney.

The increasing activities of SOD and CAT in liver and kidney after acute exposure to MC appear to be due to increased generation of reactive oxygen species. Activities of both SOD and CAT decreased oxidative stress by dismutation of superoxide radicals and decomposition to hydrogen peroxide. These findings are in accordance with those of Rai and Sharma, (2007) and Rai et al. (2009), who reported that single high doses of carbofuran treatments caused an increase in the activities of SOD and CAT in the liver, brain and erythrocytes of rat. In other study, Sharma et al. (2005) reported that single dose (1/4 of LD50) of dimethoate treatment caused an increase in the activities of the SOD and CAT in the liver and brain of rats. Pretreatment of vitamin E showed decrease in the activities of the SOD and CAT, which indicates that vitamin E and taurine provide protection against MC-induced oxidative stress. Similar results were also observed by Garg et al. (2008), who reported that the pretreatment with vitamin E moderated the activity of SOD after single dose of methomyl administration in rat erythrocytes.

GSH-Px converts hydrogen peroxide or other lipid hydroperoxides to water or hydroxyl lipids, and in this process, GSH is converted to GSSG. To recycle GSSG, the cell utilizes the enzyme GSH-Rd (Matés, 2000). MC caused a significant increase in the activity of GSH-Px in the liver and kidney of rat confirming the increased production of reactive oxygen species caused by acute administration of MC. Among the relevant studies, in an investigation carried out by Sharma et al. (2005), it was reported that acute exposure to dimethoate (1/4 LD50) caused an induction in the activity of GSH-Px in the liver and brain of rat. Sutcu et al. (2007) also reported that single dose (1/4 LD50) of diazinon administration caused an increase in the activity of GSH-Px in the rat erythrocytes. GSH-Rd is an important secondary antioxidant enzyme required to maintain high GSH/GSSG ratios (Carlberg and Mannervik, 1985). In the present study, GSH-Rd remained unchanged in the liver and kidney of rat after acute exposure to MC indicating disturbances in the activities of the enzyme regulating glutathione metabolism. El-Sharkawy et al. (1994) also reported no difference on the activity of GSH-Rd in mice liver following single oral administration of carbaryl.

As clearly demonstrated, the protective effects of vitamin E and taurine on MC induced oxidative stress in liver and kidney resulted from antioxidant activity including stabilization in the intracellular defense systems and reductions in the production of reactive oxygen species. It has been reported previously that vitamin E is protective against pesticide-induced toxicity (Aldana et al., 2001; Atessahin et al., 2005; el-Demerdash et al., 2004; Garg et al., 2008; Giray et al., 2001; John et al., 2001; Kalender et al., 2004; 2005; Ozden et al., 2009; Yousef et al., 2006). Studies also reported that taurine is known to attenuate tissue lipid peroxidation either by scavenging or quenching oxygen-derived free radicals, directly or by binding free metal ion species (Franconi et al., 2004; Hagar, 2004). As far as we know, this is the first report to demonstrate that the pretreatment with taurine may have a prominent protective effect against single high dose of pesticide-induced oxidative stress in the liver and kidney of rat as well.

We observed higher GSH levels in liver than the kidney tissues of MC-treated rats. A higher GSH level might reflect a high antioxidant status/redox potential that results in lower TBARS accumulation. These results demonstrate that the MC treatment might increase oxidative stress in kidney more than liver. The results of histological observations showed that acute MC administration leads to less degenerative changes in the morphology of the liver than the kidney tissue confirming the GSH results. Moreover, pretreatment of vitamin E and taurine decreased MC-induced degenerative damage in kidney, while they had no effect in liver. We have shown similar results for subacute exposure to MC in our previous study (Ozden et al., 2009). The inability of vitamin E and taurine to prevent the histological changes in the liver tissue indicates that some other factors may also be involved in the pathway. Michalk et al. (1983) have shown that acute renal failure increased taurine levels in the liver. Thus, we can suggest that increased taurine level might defense against oxidative stress in MC-induced liver toxicity that occurred with kidney injury in our model. Therefore, we could not observe any morphologic alteration in liver with taurine and vitamin E administration. On the other hand, we observed more damage in kidney, because of lacking antioxidant defense. Moreover, it has been showed that FMO1, which is the major kidney isoform, catalyzed the activation and detoxification of carbamate compounds more efficiently than FMO3, which is the major liver isoform (Furnes and Schlenk, 2004; Schlenk et al., 2002). So, we can suggest that MC undergoes a series of metabolism reactions in kidney much more than in liver by the pathway of FMOs. All these data explained the differences in our histological observations.

In conclusion, the administration of MC to male rats at a single dose of 25 mg/kg b.w. caused lipid peroxidation and significant changes on antioxidant defense systems and histology of the liver and kidney. It has been shown that the biochemical parameters could be affected easily than the histological parameters. Furthermore, pretreatment of vitamin E and taurine may attenuate MC-induced oxidative damage by decreasing lipid peroxidation and altering antioxidant defense system in the liver and kidney of rat. However, vitamin E and taurine might reduce histological changes related with oxidative stress in the kidney more significantly than in the liver of MC-treated rats. MC-induced acute toxicity via free radical mechanism has not been previously reported; therefore, the present study represents a possible pathway for the mechanism of MC-induced toxicity.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors thank Prof. Dr Tuncay Altug and people who work in the animal house of Cerrahpasa Faculty of Medicine, Istanbul University for their help in this study. Additionally, the authors also appreciate Mehtap Sahin for her technical support in the preparation of histological samples.

fn.p: This work was supported by the Research Fund of Istanbul University (T-338/03112003).
